questions.question: A primary tax advantage of operating as a C corporation is:

options.A: Single level of taxation on business income
options.B: Ability to accumulate earnings at lower corporate tax rates
options.C: Pass-through of losses to shareholders

questions.explanation: C corporations can accumulate earnings at the flat 21% corporate rate, which may be lower than individual rates. However, this creates potential double taxation when earnings are distributed. C corps do not have pass-through taxation, and dividends paid are not deductible.
questions.tip: C corp = 21% flat rate for accumulation. Good when shareholders are in higher individual brackets.

questions.question: The IRS may recharacterize excessive shareholder-employee compensation as:

options.A: A loan to the shareholder
options.B: A constructive dividend
options.C: A return of capital

questions.explanation: If compensation paid to shareholder-employees exceeds reasonable amounts, the IRS may recharacterize the excess as a constructive dividend. This eliminates the corporate deduction, creates double taxation, and may impose penalties. Documentation of reasonable compensation is essential.
questions.tip: C corp owner compensation must be reasonable. Excess → constructive dividend → no deduction + double tax.

questions.question: The current federal corporate income tax rate for C corporations is:
questions.explanation: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act established a flat 21% corporate tax rate beginning in 2018, replacing the prior graduated rate structure that ranged from 15% to 35%. This flat rate applies to all taxable income regardless of amount.
questions.tip: C corp rate = flat 21% since 2018 (TCJA). No longer graduated.

questions.question: Qualified dividends from a C corporation are taxed to individual shareholders at:

options.A: Ordinary income rates
options.B: Preferential capital gain rates (0%, 15%, or 20%)
options.C: A flat 21% rate

questions.explanation: Qualified dividends (meeting holding period requirements) are taxed at preferential long-term capital gain rates: 0% for taxpayers in the 10-12% brackets, 15% for middle brackets, and 20% for the highest bracket. Ordinary dividends are taxed at regular income rates.
questions.tip: Qualified dividends = 0%/15%/20% rates (same as LTCG). Must meet holding period requirement.

questions.question: For Section 351 to apply to a corporate formation, the transferors must:

options.A: Control at least 50% of the corporation immediately after the exchange
options.B: Control at least 80% of the corporation immediately after the exchange
options.C: Be U.S. citizens or residents

questions.explanation: Section 351 provides nonrecognition treatment when property is transferred to a corporation solely in exchange for stock, if the transferors control (80% or more of voting power and total shares) the corporation immediately after the exchange. Services do not qualify as property for this purpose.
questions.tip: Section 351 = 80% control test, immediately after exchange. Services ≠ property.

questions.question: A C corporation's net operating loss (NOL) arising after 2020 can offset taxable income by up to:

options.A: 50% of taxable income in any carryforward year
options.B: 80% of taxable income in any carryforward year
options.C: 100% of taxable income in any carryforward year

questions.explanation: For NOLs arising after December 31, 2020, the deduction is limited to 80% of taxable income (before the NOL deduction). The NOL can be carried forward indefinitely but cannot be carried back (except for certain farm losses). The 80% limit ensures some minimum tax is paid.
questions.tip: Post-2020 NOLs: 80% limitation, indefinite carryforward, no carryback (generally).

questions.question: In calculating accumulated taxable income for the accumulated earnings tax, a corporation is allowed an accumulated earnings credit of at least:
questions.explanation: Most corporations receive a minimum accumulated earnings credit of $250,000 ($150,000 for certain personal service corporations). This allows accumulation up to these amounts without risk of the accumulated earnings tax, even without documented business needs.
questions.tip: AET credit: $250K for most corps, $150K for personal service corps. Safe harbor for accumulation.

questions.question: A corporation is a personal holding company (PHC) if it meets the stock ownership test AND:

options.A: At least 40% of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income
options.B: At least 50% of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income
options.C: At least 60% of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income
options.D: At least 80% of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income

questions.explanation: A corporation is a PHC if: (1) more than 50% of stock is owned by 5 or fewer individuals at any time during the last half of the tax year, AND (2) at least 60% of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income (dividends, interest, rents, royalties, personal service contracts). PHCs face a 20% tax on undistributed PHC income.
questions.tip: PHC = 5-or-fewer own >50% + 60%+ PHC income. Pay dividends to avoid 20% PHC tax.

questions.question: Section 162(m) limits the deduction for compensation paid to covered employees of publicly traded corporations to:

options.A: $500,000 per year
options.B: $1,000,000 per year
options.C: $2,000,000 per year

questions.explanation: Section 162(m) limits the deduction for compensation paid to covered employees of publicly traded corporations to $1 million per year. After TCJA, covered employees include CEO, CFO, and the three highest-paid officers, with no exception for performance-based compensation.
questions.tip: 162(m) = $1M cap per covered employee. Performance-based exception eliminated by TCJA.

questions.question: A C corporation receiving dividends from an unrelated domestic corporation in which it owns 30% of the stock is entitled to a dividends received deduction of:
questions.explanation: The dividends received deduction depends on ownership percentage: 50% DRD for less than 20% ownership, 65% DRD for 20% to less than 80% ownership, and 100% DRD for 80% or more ownership (affiliated group). With 30% ownership, the 65% DRD applies.

questions.question: For a stock redemption to be treated as a sale (rather than a dividend), the distribution must:

options.A: Be pro rata to all shareholders
options.B: Meet one of several tests showing meaningful reduction in interest
options.C: Be from a publicly traded corporation
options.D: Be paid within one year of the board resolution

questions.explanation: A redemption is treated as a sale (eligible for capital gain treatment) only if it meets one of several tests: complete termination of interest, substantially disproportionate distribution, not essentially equivalent to a dividend (meaningful reduction), or partial liquidation. Otherwise, it's taxed as a dividend to the extent of E&P.
questions.tip: Redemption as sale requires: complete termination, substantially disproportionate, or meaningful reduction.

questions.question: A C corporation's charitable contribution deduction is limited to what percentage of taxable income (before certain deductions)?
questions.explanation: C corporations can deduct charitable contributions up to 10% of taxable income computed before the charitable contribution deduction, DRD, NOL deduction, and certain other items. Excess contributions can be carried forward 5 years.
questions.tip: Corporate charitable limit = 10% of modified taxable income. 5-year carryforward for excess.

questions.question: C corporation capital losses can only:

options.A: Offset capital gains; excess carried back 3 years, forward 5 years
options.B: Offset up to $3,000 of ordinary income annually
options.C: Be converted to ordinary losses through Section 1244
options.D: Offset any type of income without limitation

questions.explanation: C corporations can only use capital losses to offset capital gains - there is no $3,000 ordinary income offset like individuals have. Net capital losses can be carried back 3 years and forward 5 years (all as short-term). Unused losses expire after the 5-year carryforward period.
questions.tip: Corp capital losses: only offset gains, carry back 3/forward 5 (all short-term). No ordinary income offset.

questions.question: A 'large corporation' for estimated tax purposes cannot use the prior year's tax for safe harbor after:

options.A: The first estimated payment
options.B: The second estimated payment
options.C: The third estimated payment

questions.explanation: Large corporations (taxable income of $1 million or more in any of the 3 preceding years) can use prior year tax for only the first quarterly estimated payment. Remaining payments must be based on current year liability. Any shortfall from the first quarter must be made up in the second quarter.
questions.tip: Large corp = prior year safe harbor only for Q1. Must use current year estimate for Q2-Q4.

questions.question: A major advantage of C corporation status for owner-employees is:

options.A: Deduction of health insurance premiums above-the-line
options.B: Tax-free fringe benefits even for more-than-2% shareholders
options.C: No limit on retirement plan contributions
options.D: Deduction of personal expenses as business expenses

questions.explanation: C corporation shareholder-employees can receive tax-free fringe benefits (health insurance, group term life up to $50,000, etc.) regardless of ownership percentage. S corp shareholders owning more than 2% cannot exclude these benefits from income. This is a significant C corp planning advantage.
questions.tip: C corp = full fringe benefits for owner-employees. S corp >2% shareholders can't exclude health insurance.

questions.question: In a complete liquidation of a C corporation:

options.A: Only shareholders recognize gain or loss
options.B: Only the corporation recognizes gain or loss
options.C: Both corporation and shareholders may recognize gain or loss
options.D: Neither party recognizes gain or loss

questions.explanation: In a complete liquidation, the corporation recognizes gain or loss as if it sold its assets at FMV (Section 336). Shareholders recognize gain or loss on the exchange of stock for liquidating distributions (Section 331). This results in potential double taxation on appreciated assets.
questions.tip: C corp liquidation = double tax: corporate level on asset appreciation + shareholder level on stock exchange.

questions.question: Thin capitalization (high debt-to-equity ratio) creates risk that shareholder loans will be recharacterized as:

options.A: Preferred stock
options.B: Common stock (equity contribution)
options.C: Guaranteed payments

questions.explanation: When a corporation is thinly capitalized (excessive debt relative to equity), the IRS may recharacterize shareholder loans as equity contributions. This converts deductible interest payments into nondeductible dividends and eliminates basis for loan repayment. A reasonable debt-to-equity ratio helps support debt treatment.
questions.tip: Thin capitalization risk: loans → equity. Interest → dividend (no deduction). Document arm's-length loan terms.

questions.question: A C corporation may select any fiscal year-end because:

options.A: The required taxable year rules don't apply to C corps
options.B: C corps are required to use a calendar year
options.C: The IRS automatically approves any fiscal year
options.D: Pass-through taxation rules mandate calendar years

questions.explanation: C corporations are not subject to the required taxable year rules that apply to partnerships, S corporations, and personal service corporations. They can generally select any fiscal year-end (though newly formed corporations must use the year shown on Form 1120 for the first return).
questions.tip: C corps have fiscal year flexibility. S corps and partnerships must generally use calendar year.

questions.question: The primary purpose of calculating earnings and profits (E&P) is to:

options.A: Determine the corporation's tax liability
options.B: Calculate the amount of distributions taxable as dividends
options.C: Determine shareholders' stock basis

questions.explanation: E&P measures a corporation's economic ability to pay dividends. Distributions are dividends (taxable to shareholders) to the extent of current and accumulated E&P. Distributions exceeding E&P are return of capital (reducing stock basis), then capital gain if basis is exhausted.
questions.tip: E&P determines dividend treatment: distribution up to E&P = dividend; excess = return of capital → capital gain.

questions.question: In a Section 351 exchange, if the corporation assumes liabilities in excess of the transferor's basis in property transferred:

options.A: The entire transaction is disqualified from Section 351
options.B: Only the excess is recognized as gain
options.C: The excess is treated as a loan from the corporation
options.D: The transferor recognizes gain equal to the excess

questions.explanation: Under Section 357(c), if liabilities assumed exceed the transferor's basis in property transferred, the excess is recognized as gain. This prevents taxpayers from extracting tax-free cash by having the corporation assume liabilities greater than their investment. The character is determined by the property transferred.
questions.tip: 357(c): Liabilities > basis = gain. Can't extract tax-free cash through excessive liability assumption.

questions.question: When a C corporation distributes appreciated property to shareholders:

options.A: No gain is recognized by the corporation
options.B: The corporation recognizes gain as if the property were sold at FMV
options.C: Shareholders take carryover basis in the property
options.D: The distribution reduces E&P by the property's basis

questions.explanation: When a C corporation distributes appreciated property, it recognizes gain as if it sold the property at FMV (Section 311(b)). Shareholders receive dividend treatment to the extent of E&P and take FMV basis in the property. E&P is reduced by FMV, not basis.
questions.tip: C corp property distribution: corp recognizes gain on appreciation, shareholder gets FMV basis.

questions.question: Form 1120 for a calendar-year C corporation is due:

options.A: March 15
options.B: April 15
options.C: September 15

questions.explanation: C corporation returns (Form 1120) are due on the 15th day of the 4th month after year-end. For calendar-year corporations, this is April 15. A 6-month extension (to October 15) is available. This differs from S corporations and partnerships, which are due March 15.
questions.tip: C corp = April 15 due date (4th month). S corp/partnership = March 15 (3rd month).

questions.question: Under Section 163(j), business interest expense is generally limited to:

options.A: 50% of taxable income
options.B: 30% of adjusted taxable income plus business interest income
options.C: The greater of $25 million or 30% of gross receipts

questions.explanation: Section 163(j) limits business interest deductions to business interest income plus 30% of adjusted taxable income (ATI). ATI excludes interest, depreciation (through 2025), and amortization. Disallowed interest carries forward indefinitely. Small businesses (under $30M gross receipts) are exempt.
questions.tip: 163(j): Business interest limited to 30% ATI + interest income. Small business exception at $30M.

questions.question: After an ownership change, Section 382 limits the annual use of pre-change NOLs to:

options.A: 20% of the NOL balance
options.B: The Section 382 limitation (value × long-term tax-exempt rate)
options.C: 50% of post-change taxable income
options.D: The amount of post-change taxable income

questions.explanation: After an ownership change (more than 50% shift in ownership over 3 years), annual use of pre-change NOLs is limited to the Section 382 limitation: the corporation's value at the ownership change date multiplied by the federal long-term tax-exempt rate. This prevents trafficking in NOLs.
questions.tip: Section 382 limit = company value × long-term tax-exempt rate. Prevents NOL trafficking after ownership changes.

questions.question: For a redemption to be 'substantially disproportionate' under Section 302(b)(2), the shareholder must own after the redemption:

options.A: Less than 80% of pre-redemption voting power and less than 80% of common stock
options.B: Less than 50% of voting power and less than 50% of total value
options.C: Less than 80% of pre-redemption percentage AND less than 50% voting power
options.D: Less than 100% of any class of stock

questions.explanation: A substantially disproportionate redemption requires: (1) after the redemption, the shareholder owns less than 50% of total voting power, AND (2) the shareholder's percentage of voting stock AND common stock is less than 80% of the pre-redemption percentage. Both conditions must be met.
questions.tip: Substantially disproportionate: <50% voting power AND <80% of prior percentage for both voting and common.

questions.question: A Type A reorganization is characterized by:

options.A: Stock-for-stock exchange between unrelated corporations
options.B: Statutory merger or consolidation
options.C: Transfer of assets solely for voting stock

questions.explanation: A Type A reorganization is a statutory merger or consolidation under state law. It offers the most flexibility in consideration used (can include some cash and other property). Other types: Type B (stock-for-stock), Type C (assets-for-voting stock), Type D (divisive or acquisitive), Type E (recapitalization), Type F (change in form).
questions.tip: Type A = statutory merger. Most flexible on consideration. Other letters = more restrictions on what can be exchanged.

questions.question: To file a consolidated return, the parent corporation must own what percentage of the subsidiary's stock?

options.A: At least 50% of voting power
options.B: More than 50% of voting power and value
options.C: At least 80% of voting power and 80% of value

questions.explanation: An affiliated group eligible to file a consolidated return requires the common parent to own at least 80% of the voting power and 80% of the total value of the stock of each includible subsidiary. Once elected, all members must file consolidated. Certain corporations (S corps, foreign corps, tax-exempt entities) are excluded.
questions.tip: Consolidated return = 80% voting + 80% value. Election binds all members once made.

questions.question: Which of the following increases current E&P but not taxable income?

options.A: Depreciation in excess of straight-line
options.B: Tax-exempt interest income
options.C: Federal income taxes paid

questions.explanation: Tax-exempt interest increases E&P but not taxable income - it represents economic income available for dividends. Conversely, federal taxes reduce E&P but not taxable income. DRD reduces taxable income but not E&P. Accelerated depreciation in excess of straight-line reduces taxable income more than E&P.
questions.tip: E&P = economic income for dividends. Add: tax-exempt income, life insurance proceeds. Subtract: federal taxes.

questions.question: A Section 338 election allows the acquiring corporation to:

options.A: Avoid gain recognition on the stock purchase
options.B: Treat a stock acquisition as an asset acquisition for tax purposes
options.C: Defer recognition of the premium paid over book value
options.D: Convert ordinary income to capital gain

questions.explanation: Section 338 allows an acquiring corporation that purchases at least 80% of target stock within 12 months to elect to treat the acquisition as a deemed asset purchase for tax purposes. This steps up asset basis (creating depreciation deductions) but triggers immediate gain recognition at the target level.
questions.tip: Section 338 = treat stock purchase as asset purchase. Get basis step-up but trigger target-level gain.

questions.question: GILTI (Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income) represents income of controlled foreign corporations that:

options.A: Exceeds a deemed return on tangible depreciable assets
options.B: Is derived from passive investments
options.C: Has already been taxed in the foreign jurisdiction
options.D: Is attributable to intangible property transferred abroad

questions.explanation: GILTI is the excess of a CFC's tested income over 10% of its qualified business asset investment (QBAI - depreciable tangible assets). It's designed to tax income exceeding a routine return on tangible assets, presumed to be attributable to intangibles. U.S. shareholders of CFCs include GILTI in income annually.
questions.tip: GILTI = CFC income above 10% return on tangible assets. Targets excess returns attributable to intangibles.

questions.question: The Base Erosion and Anti-Abuse Tax (BEAT) applies to corporations with:

options.A: Any base erosion payments to foreign affiliates
options.B: Average gross receipts of $500 million+ and base erosion percentage of 3%+
options.C: More than 50% foreign ownership
options.D: Foreign tax credits exceeding U.S. tax liability

questions.explanation: BEAT applies to corporations with average annual gross receipts of $500 million or more over 3 years AND a base erosion percentage of at least 3% (2% for certain banks/dealers). BEAT is a minimum tax on modified taxable income, adding back deductible payments to foreign affiliates.
questions.tip: BEAT = minimum tax for large corps with significant deductible payments to foreign affiliates. $500M+ receipts, 3%+ erosion.

questions.question: For a tax-free corporate spin-off under Section 355, both the distributing corporation and the spun-off subsidiary must:

options.A: Have been in existence for at least 1 year
options.B: Be engaged in an active trade or business for at least 5 years
options.C: Be of approximately equal value

questions.explanation: Section 355 requires both the distributing corporation and the controlled corporation to be engaged in active trades or businesses immediately after the distribution, with each business conducted for at least 5 years before the distribution. Other requirements include distribution for a valid business purpose, not principally a device to distribute E&P, and continuity of interest.
questions.tip: Section 355 spin-off: both entities need 5-year active business, valid business purpose, not a device for E&P distribution.

questions.question: For stock to qualify as qualified small business stock (QSBS) under Section 1202, the issuing corporation must have aggregate gross assets not exceeding what amount at the time of issuance?

options.A: $5 million
options.B: $25 million
options.C: $50 million

questions.explanation: Section 1202 QSBS requires the issuing C corporation to have aggregate gross assets not exceeding $50 million at the time of stock issuance (and immediately after). Gross assets include cash received for the stock. The corporation must also be engaged in a qualified trade or business (certain service businesses are excluded).
questions.tip: QSBS gross asset limit = $50M at issuance. Must be C corp in qualified active business.

questions.question: A brother-sister controlled group exists when 5 or fewer individuals, estates, or trusts own:

options.A: At least 50% of each corporation considering only identical ownership
options.B: More than 50% of each corporation AND more than 50% identical ownership
options.C: At least 80% of each corporation
options.D: 100% of one corporation and more than 50% of another

questions.explanation: A brother-sister controlled group requires: (1) 5 or fewer persons own more than 50% of each corporation's stock (voting power or value), AND (2) the same persons own more than 50% of each corporation considering only their identical ownership (the lesser percentage owned in each). Controlled groups must share certain tax benefits.
questions.tip: Brother-sister: 5 or fewer own >50% of each + >50% identical ownership. Share brackets, AMT exemption, etc.

questions.question: The Foreign-Derived Intangible Income (FDII) deduction benefits domestic C corporations by:

options.A: Excluding all foreign-source income
options.B: Providing a deduction for income from exports exceeding routine returns
options.C: Eliminating taxation on income from intangible property
options.D: Allowing deferral of tax on foreign subsidiary income

questions.explanation: FDII provides a deduction for U.S. corporations on income from serving foreign markets (exports) that exceeds a routine return on tangible assets. The deduction results in an effective tax rate of approximately 13.125% on FDII (compared to 21% regular rate). FDII mirrors GILTI as an incentive to keep intangibles in the U.S.
questions.tip: FDII = export incentive. Effective 13.125% rate on income from serving foreign markets (vs. 21% regular rate).
